items.title: Trump approves CIA operations in Venezuela, Maduro says 'no to regime change'
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump confirmed Wednesday that he had authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela, significantly intensifying US pressure on President Nicolas Maduro's government. Trump also revealed he was considering launching strikes against Venezuelan drug cartels on land, following a series of deadly maritime operations targeting alleged narcotics-smuggling vessels.
items.content: US President Donald Trump confirmed Wednesday that he had authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela, significantly intensifying US pressure on President Nicolas Maduro's government. Trump also revealed he was considering launching strikes against Venezuelan drug cartels on land, following a series of deadly maritime operations targeting alleged narcotics-smuggling vessels.

items.title: Trump authorized CIA action inside Venezuela
items.standfirst: President Trump said he is considering land strikes against drug cartels after U.S. military strikes on alleged drug boats off Venezuela. He also revealed he has authorized CIA action inside Venezuela. NBC News’ Courtney Kube reports.
items.content: President Trump said he is considering land strikes against drug cartels after U.S. military strikes on alleged drug boats off Venezuela. He also revealed he has authorized CIA action inside Venezuela. NBC News’ Courtney Kube reports.

items.title: Trump authorises CIA operations in Venezuela, says mulling land attack
items.standfirst: US president refused to directly answer whether he was trying to topple the Maduro government as tensions escalate.
items.content: US president refused to directly answer whether he was trying to topple the Maduro government as tensions escalate.

items.title: Venezuela's president pleads for peace after Trump sends in CIA
items.standfirst: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro has accused the US of a coup attempt after Donald Trump approved CIA operations in the country to tackle alleged drug trafficking.
items.content: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro has accused the US of a coup attempt after Donald Trump approved CIA operations in the country to tackle alleged drug trafficking.

items.title: Trump confirms he authorized CIA action in Venezuela
items.standfirst: The CIA's operations are usually shrouded in secrecy, but Trump said on Wednesday he had authorized the spy agency to take unspecified action in Venezuela.
items.content: The CIA's operations are usually shrouded in secrecy, but Trump said on Wednesday he had authorized the spy agency to take unspecified action in Venezuela.

items.title: Lawmakers frustrated over lack of intel from Trump administration over Venezuela strikes
items.standfirst: Six sources tell NBC News that members of Congress are growing increasingly concerned over a lack of information from the Trump administration about the attacks on alleged drug smuggling boats. NBC News' Courtney Kube reports on the strikes as well as the Pentagon's updated press policy.
items.content: Six sources tell NBC News that members of Congress are growing increasingly concerned over a lack of information from the Trump administration about the attacks on alleged drug smuggling boats. NBC News' Courtney Kube reports on the strikes as well as the Pentagon's updated press policy.

ai_summary: Trump confirmed he authorized covert CIA operations in Venezuela, escalating pressure on Maduro.
Maduro rejected the CIA operations, calling them "coups d'etat" orchestrated by the agency.
The authorization marks a significant escalation in the US's pressure campaign against Maduro's government.
Trump suggested considering strikes on Venezuelan territory, a dramatic step beyond recent attacks.
The move follows deadly strikes against alleged drug-smuggling boats in the Caribbean by the US military.

items.title: US may take strategic stakes in rare earths companies to tackle China ‘power grab’
items.standfirst: Treasury secretary Scott Bessent raises possibility of taking more direct stakes in companies to protect national security in wake of Beijing’s curbs on rare earths exportsThe Trump administration has criticised China’s increased restrictions on rare earth exports as a threat to global supply chains, and said it would seek to tighten control over strategic sectors by taking more stakes in key companies to counter Beijing.Treasury secretary Scott Bessent told an event on Wednesday that China’s dramatic new restrictions on rare earth minerals and magnets demonstrated the need for the US to be self-sufficient in critical materials or rely more on trusted allies. Continue reading...
items.content: Treasury secretary Scott Bessent raises possibility of taking more direct stakes in companies to protect national security in wake of Beijing’s curbs on rare earths exportsThe Trump administration has criticised China’s increased restrictions on rare earth exports as a threat to global supply chains, and said it would seek to tighten control over strategic sectors by taking more stakes in key companies to counter Beijing.Treasury secretary Scott Bessent told an event on Wednesday that China’s dramatic new restrictions on rare earth minerals and magnets demonstrated the need for the US to be self-sufficient in critical materials or rely more on trusted allies. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US may take strategic stakes in rare earths companies to counter China.
This is to protect national security amid Beijing's restrictions on exports.
The Trump administration criticizes China's restrictions as a threat.

items.title: Live: UN chief urges Israel to open more crossings to allow aid into Gaza
items.standfirst: United Nations relief chief Tom Fletcher has urged Israel to open more crossings into the famine-stricken Gaza Strip so that aid can be delivered. Follow our liveblog for all the latest.

items.content: Colonel Randrianirina set to assume presidency in Madagascar after President Andry Rajoelina removed.

items.title: African Union suspends Madagascar as military leader set to be sworn in as president
items.standfirst: Army assumed power after parliament voted to impeach Andry Rajoelina following widespread protestsMadagascar’s new military ruler will be sworn in as the country’s president on Friday, the military said on Wednesday, as the African Union suspended the island nation after a coup that ousted President Andry Rajoelina.The Indian Ocean nation has been plunged into its worst political upheaval in years after the elite Capsat army unit assumed power on Tuesday, moments after parliament voted to impeach Rajoelina, who appeared to have fled the country as street protests escalated. Continue reading...
items.content: Army assumed power after parliament voted to impeach Andry Rajoelina following widespread protestsMadagascar’s new military ruler will be sworn in as the country’s president on Friday, the military said on Wednesday, as the African Union suspended the island nation after a coup that ousted President Andry Rajoelina.The Indian Ocean nation has been plunged into its worst political upheaval in years after the elite Capsat army unit assumed power on Tuesday, moments after parliament voted to impeach Rajoelina, who appeared to have fled the country as street protests escalated. Continue reading...

items.title: Elite military unit says it has seized power in Madagascar
items.standfirst: Announcement comes after country’s parliament impeaches president after weeks of anti-government protestsAn elite military unit said it had taken power in Madagascar on Tuesday, after the country’s parliament impeached president Andry Rajoelina after weeks of anti-government protests.Rajoelina, who said on Monday in a Facebook Live video that he had gone into hiding after attempts to kill him, had refused demands to step down, but the demonstrators won the backing of the influential Capsat unit at the weekend. Continue reading...
items.content: Announcement comes after country’s parliament impeaches president after weeks of anti-government protestsAn elite military unit said it had taken power in Madagascar on Tuesday, after the country’s parliament impeached president Andry Rajoelina after weeks of anti-government protests.Rajoelina, who said on Monday in a Facebook Live video that he had gone into hiding after attempts to kill him, had refused demands to step down, but the demonstrators won the backing of the influential Capsat unit at the weekend. Continue reading...

A military leader is set to be sworn in as president.
The coup occurred after parliament impeached President Rajoelina.
Widespread protests preceded the impeachment and military takeover.
The elite Capsat army unit seized power in Madagascar.

clusters.title: Syria’s al-Sharaa seeks to ‘redefine’ Russia ties in first Moscow visit

items.title: Syria’s al-Sharaa seeks to ‘redefine’ Russia ties in first Moscow visit
items.standfirst: During his first state visit to Moscow, Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa vowed to ‘redefine’ ties with Russia.
items.content: During his first state visit to Moscow, Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa vowed to ‘redefine’ ties with Russia.

items.title: Syrian leader seeks reset in Russia relations in Putin meeting
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa said Wednesday he wanted to "redefine" relations with Moscow as Russian President Vladimir Putin hosted him in their first meeting since key Kremlin ally Bashar al-Assad was ousted last year. In front of the television cameras, Putin greeted Sharaa warmly at the Kremlin, but behind closed doors the Syrian leader was expected to push for Moscow to extradite Assad, who fled there after being toppled.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa said Wednesday he wanted to "redefine" relations with Moscow as Russian President Vladimir Putin hosted him in their first meeting since key Kremlin ally Bashar al-Assad was ousted last year. In front of the television cameras, Putin greeted Sharaa warmly at the Kremlin, but behind closed doors the Syrian leader was expected to push for Moscow to extradite Assad, who fled there after being toppled.

items.title: Syria's Sharaa tells Putin he will respect past deals with Moscow
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa told Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday he would honour all past deals struck between his country and Moscow, a pledge suggesting Moscow's two main military bases in Syria are safe.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa told Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday he would honour all past deals struck between his country and Moscow, a pledge suggesting Moscow's two main military bases in Syria are safe.

ai_summary: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa met with Vladimir Putin in Moscow.
Al-Sharaa wants to "redefine" relations with Russia.
Putin hosted al-Sharaa in their first meeting since Assad's ouster.
Al-Sharaa pledged to honor past deals with Moscow.
The meeting suggests Moscow's bases in Syria are safe.

clusters.title: ChatGPT erotica coming soon with age verification, CEO says
clusters.neutral_headline: ChatGPT erotica coming soon with age verification, CEO says

items.title: ChatGPT erotica coming soon with age verification, CEO says
items.standfirst: Sam Altman claims new tools can detect mental distress while relaxing limits for adults.
items.content: On Tuesday, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman announced that the company will allow verified adult users to have erotic conversations with ChatGPT starting in December. The change represents a shift in how OpenAI approaches content restrictions, which the company had loosened in February but then dramatically tightened after an August lawsuit from parents of a teen who died by suicide after allegedly receiving encouragement from ChatGPT. "In December, as we roll out age-gating more fully and as part of our 'treat adult users like adults' principle, we will allow even more, like erotica for verified adults," Altman wrote in his post on X (formerly Twitter). The announcement follows OpenAI's recent hint that it would allow developers to create "mature" ChatGPT applications once the company implements appropriate age verification and controls. Altman explained that OpenAI had made ChatGPT "pretty restrictive to make sure we were being careful with mental health issues" but acknowledged this approach made the chatbot "less useful/enjoyable to many users who had no mental health problems." The CEO said the company now has new tools to better detect when users are experiencing mental distress, allowing OpenAI to relax restrictions in most cases.Read full article Comments

items.title: ChatGPT will soon allow erotica for verified adults, says OpenAI boss
items.standfirst: CEO Sam Altman says upcoming versions of the popular chatbot would enable it to behave in a more human-like way - "but only if you want it".
items.content: CEO Sam Altman says upcoming versions of the popular chatbot would enable it to behave in a more human-like way - "but only if you want it".

ai_summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman announced ChatGPT will allow erotica.
Age verification will be required for access to the content.
New tools will detect mental distress, according to Altman.
The changes relax limits for adult users.
The chatbot will behave in a more human-like way.
